The tea party is simply the latest incarnation of the thinking of John C. Calhoun of South Carolina. Calhoun proposed that states have the right to nullify any federal law they do not like (the Nullification Crisis of 1832). Old Hickory (President Andrew Jackson, also a southerner), became so outraged by Calhoun's actions that he was ready to lead the troops to South Carolina and hang Calhoun (the crisis was defused by Henry Clay and Old Hickory did not hang Calhoun; although, Old Hickory did say on his deathbed that his greatest regret in life was that he didn't hang Calhoun and shoot Clay).

The notion that states can ignore the federal government came to a head in 1860 with the election of Lincoln. The pro-slave states didn't bother with nullification this time; they simply seceded from the union.

Today, tea party types still think they can nullify federal laws (e.g., trying to shut down the government to nullify the ACA). One of my state (NE) legislators proposed a bill that would allow Nebraskans to nullify any federal gun-control law (the bill did not make it out of committee).

We fought a Civil War to determine that the federal government is sovereign. Yet, many citizens still think they can oppose federal laws they do not like ("Don't Tread on Me"). Thus proving Mencken correct: "You will never go broke underestimating the intelligence of the American public."

They, and other big market teams, pay premium prices for older players because they have to justify the ticket prices. But something more fundamental is going on; there are simply too many teams and too many players, many of whom cannot play at this level. The game has been diluted.

Add in the ridiculous number of high school and college all star teams, camps, weight training etc. and you have a noticeable increase in overuse injuries. Last night one of the top ten picks in the draft had Tommy John surgery and won't be able to play for 15 months. Pretty soon you'll see overzealous fathers opting for their sons to have the surgery while in the Little League, just to get it out of the way.

Baseball is one of the few games in which yesterday's stars would still be stars today. How would Ted, Joe, Hank, Willie, Mick stand up to today's players. Pretty well is my guess. Actually better than just good; they'd be facing a lot of double and triple A quality pitchers.

Like many things in life, money ruined baseball.
Without Tanaka pitching and Yangervis Solarte hitting, the Yankee$ would be duking it out with the Rays for fifth place.

I'm a Yankee fan for life, and agree.  Its one thing if adding one more key guy really looks like it could put you over the top, but you just can't build your team around old and/or injury prone guys.  It only works if you get really, really lucky.  I'd much rather see talented kids getting a chance to see if they can play at the MLB level and really busting their rears than watching retreads do great once in a while but break down or struggle way too much.  All this is doubly true in the post-steroids era.

The Yankees never learn their lesson. Their opponent continually replenishes their roster at a much much much lower cost and stays competitive.  The Yankees insist at paying enormous amounts to older players and have a revolving door. Without Tanaka they would be firmly established in last place - and its a long season - they still might end up there.

"Clear-cutting of mature forests is already on the rise again: it increased by 28% in 2013 and is expected to rise again this year."

Well there you go. Before I even read that quote up there I'd of bet my mangy cat something like this would be the case. And no, it is not that I am so negative, it's because logical deduction makes it so. In economics of any kind, incentives work only for a short time because with market dynamics incentives fall by the way side as other opportunities or down turns arise, leaving those incentives not as incentiveable. In the market system we are always chasing our tails in order to adjust to these market dynamics. And this case is set sure to be a tail chaser. Poor people in an economically unstable region? No way can you trust a market to regulate and government regulation is always and forever going to be a patch job that falls off with the first economic down turn. Good story Andy and I do hope I am wrong, but that quote up there tells the future of the developing world as long as we stick with our current global paradigm.
